Relevant part: The White House response is that hes not going to release his tax returns, said Kellyanne Conway, counselor to the president, during an appearance on ABCS This Week with George Stephanopoulos. We litigated this all through the election.
People didnt care, Conway added. They voted for him, and let me make this very clear: Most Americans are are very focused on what their tax returns will look like while President Trump is in office, not what his look like.

Oh I do too. It's what makes television such a fun medium, that ability to do something different now and again. Cape May was definitely that. Scrubs may have been the series to so it best, especially when balancing how to continue to be a comedy during the bleakest and most depressing episodes, such as the musical.

I wish I liked Cape May more. An episode of all Spader is a dream come true, but something about it didn't click for me. I'm tempted to watch it again, now that we know more about the back story, though.

Even looking at the relatively flat gigapixel vs the overhead shot, you can see that they match up. Second pen past the water, pretty full on the left, half full on the right. Third pen: packed. Fourth: left side full, right side very sparsely populated. The sixth is pretty hard to tell from the flat perspective, but looks about as full as it does in the overhead picture. And then you have all of the empty space in the seventh segment on back to the dirt.
I kinda always thought this was what it was, but maybe I just read the fan theory once and made it headcannon
I'm pretty partial to the very last one myself.

I enjoyed their election night coverage. The panel commentary as the night went on gave me some encouragement. I can't remember the gentlemen's name, now, the one that went on that really epic rant towards the end of the evening, but that was a really special moment for me, when I realized that some people were not going to keep their mouths shut and were still going to try to keep the sanity in news.
My problem with CNN is just the speculation on unfolding events (something all 24-hour news channels are guilty of), and the insane use of graphics (though I admit most of the time, I'm a fiend for those).
I'll try to pay more attention in the coming months/years and see what I can get out of it. I try to be a local news watcher when at all possible, and read as much as I can online (where I can fact-check fairly easily).
It does help when a rally/protest is organized like this was.
You know what, I am not the biggest fan of CNN, but that right there made them go WAY up in my estimation.

So I'm just getting started with all of this. This week I decided to kick myself into gear using Tofugu's "30 Days of Becoming A Better Japanese Learner" to try to formulate better habits.
In conjunction with that, I've tested a few new study methods, including learning, fully learning, 4 new Kanji a day. It's not a lot, but it's a quick start. I've never been good about learning everything about a kanji in all my years of study, so I'm backtracking now to fix that.
I'm also using Tofugu's 4500 sentences book to work harder on studying translation.
Next Week I will be more firmly implementing these efforts as daily routine. My goal is to learn 20 kanji soundly, write on Lang-8 4 times, and get 30 more sentences translated. I'm also reteaching myself radicals as a warm-up, and plan to finish that memrize deck by week's end.

Finished this evening, and boy... Did this book make me feel some things.
Combined with watching When Harry Met Sally on NYE (long explanation), I came to the very strong realization that I'm finally ready to start a family. It was the Happiness Machine that did me in, but the stuff that followed about memories and growing old just shook me up in a way that's hard to describe.
I've never really had a book make me feel something in this way. It's crazy. I love it. Thank you all so much for the recommendation and votes!

I'm 18% of the way through the book, according to the Kindle, and I'm just enthralled. This is one of the most breathtaking novels I've ever had the pleasure of reading. The segment as they [ Spoiler](/s 'were searching for Doug near the ravine literally had me short of breath until it finally was concluded. I did something similar to my mother when I was a kid and she's never got over it. Still brings it up to this day as one of the most frightening moments of her life.')

I grew up in the 90s and it still reminds me of my childhood. We played kick the can in my neighborhood, and ditch, and stayed out until the streetlights came on. There was a creek behind the major strip of houses in the neighborhood where we weren't allowed to play, but did anyways. I remember there being like two main groups of kids that hung out together at night, and sometimes we'd play flag football at the park. This book is definitely giving me some feelings and I'm loving it.

So, now I remember what happened. During the commercial break, while he was getting booed, he stopped reading the list and started off listing reasons why Chicago sucked, which really got the crowd going, it was pretty fun, then when they returned from break, he picked up the list at the end as though he'd gone through the whole thing.
I was 10 years old when I went to this and it was pretty much right before my parents got divorced, so it's kind of this cool bittersweetesque memory. Made me really happy to see the video, though.

You've failed me, Goodreads!
From Amazon: When Babbitt was first published in 1922, fans gleefully hailed its scathing portrait of a crass, materialistic nation; critics denounced it as an unfair skewering of the American businessman. Sparking heated literary debate, Babbitt became a controversial classic, securing Sinclair Lewiss place as one of Americas preeminent social commentators.
Businessman George F. Babbitt loves the latest appliances, brand names, and the Republican Party. In fact, he loves being a solid citizen even more than he loves his wife. But Babbitt comes to resent the middle-class trappings he has worked so hard to acquire. Realizing that his life is devoid of meaning, he grows determined to transcend his trivial existence and search for greater purpose. Raising thought-provoking questions while yielding hilarious consequences, and just as relevant today as ever, Babbitts quest for meaning forces us to confront the Babbitt in ourselvesand ponder what it truly means to be an American.

I wouldn't rely on public transportation in California to save my life. I'm right there with you. My commute to work is 30 minutes, but my commute home is an hour 15.
